items.content: A mesmerizing thriller that will grip audiences from first scene to last.
The interplay between Starling and Lector as they share an indefinable, dark understanding gives the film its unforgettable and unsettling power. [14 February 1991, Daily Notebook, p.E1]

items.author: Peter Travers
items.content: The superbly crafted suspense thrillerslams you like a sudden blast of bone-chilling, pulse-pounding terror.

items.author: Susan Wloszczyna
items.content: A movie with this kind of haunting power comes along only once every decade or so. [20 February 1991, Life, p.11D]

items.author: TV Guide Magazine
items.content: Hopkins plays the cannibalistic doctor with a quiet, controlled erudition, lacing his performance with moments of black humor. His Lecter is a sort of satanic Sherlock Holmes whose spasms of violence are all the more terrifying because they erupt from beneath such an intelligent and refined mask.

items.author: Desson Thomson
items.content: A smart, restrained entertainment, it doesn't splash around in blood and hysteria. It doesn't have to.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: It has been a good long while since I have felt the presence of Evil so manifestly demonstrated as in the first appearance of Anthony Hopkins in The Silence of the Lambs.

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: An accomplished, effective, grisly, and exceptionally sick slasher film that I can't with any conscience recommend, because the purposes to which it places its considerable ingenuity are ultimately rather foul.

items.author: Stanley Kauffmann
items.content: Demme's pacing is tight throughout, marred only by some low-angle close-ups of the cannibal that are right out of old Vincent Price thrillers. [Feb 18, 1991]

items.author: Gene Siskel
items.content: Billed as one of the most frightening, depraved films ever made. Would that it were so. Instead, this is a case of much ado about nothing. [15 February 1991, Friday, p.C]
